DOC.brief_summary: This is a four year project evaluating the effectiveness of a group-based lifestyle intervention (PeerFIT) supported by mHealth technology and social media compared to Basic Education in fitness and nutrition supported by a wearable Activity Tracking device (BEAT) in achieving clinically significant improvements in weight loss and cardiorespiratory fitness in young adults with SMI.
DOC.brief_title: Peer Support and mHealth Targeting Cardiometabolic Risk in Young Adults With Serious Mental Illness
DOC.detailed_description: The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a group-based lifestyle intervention (PeerFIT) supported by mHealth technology and social media to promote weight loss and improved fitness in young adults with SMI. The study is a two-arm randomized controlled trial conducted in real world mental health settings to evaluate the effectiveness of the 12-month PeerFIT intervention compared to Basic Education in fitness and nutrition supported by a wearable Activity Tracking device (BEAT) in achieving clinically significant improvements in weight loss and cardiorespiratory fitness. The investigators will enroll 144 overweight and obese (BMI ≥ 25) young adults ages 19 to 30 with SMI attending one of two community mental health organizations situated within the Massachusetts Department of Mental Health who are interested in losing weight and improving fitness. The investigators hypothesize that PeerFIT compared to BEAT will be associated with a greater proportion of participants who achieve cardiovascular risk reduction at 6 and 12 months follow-up as indicated by either clinically significant weight loss (5% or greater) or increased fitness (>50 m on the six-minute walk test). They will also investigate two theoretical mechanisms of action hypothesized to account for greater weight loss and increased cardiorespiratory fitness among participants assigned to PeerFIT: 1) improved self-efficacy and 2) increased peer support for health behavior change. The investigators hypothesize that the relationship between PeerFIT and weight loss and improved fitness will be mediated by improved self-efficacy and peer support for health behavior change.
DOC.criteria: Young adults ages 19 to 30 Chart diagnosis of schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar disorder, or major depression Overweight or obese defined as BMI ≥25 Enrolled in treatment at the agency for at least 3 months prior to study recruitment On the same psychiatric medications over the prior 2 months (dose changes are allowed) Able and willing to provide voluntary informed consent to participate in the study Able and willing to provide medical clearance from a primary care provider to participate in a behavioral weight loss intervention involving exercise Medical contraindication to weight loss (e.g., history of eating disorder) Cardiovascular event (e.g., myocardial infarction) within the past 6 months Major surgery planned or likely to occur within the next 6 months Prior or planned bariatric surgery Use of prescription weight loss medication within the past 6 months 20 lbs. or greater weight loss in 3 months prior to baseline Currently enrolled in another weight reduction program Pregnant or planning a pregnancy during study period Cognitive impairment sufficient to interfere with participant's ability to provide informed consent, complete study questionnaires, or participate in a group intervention as indicated by a Mini Mental Status Examination score <24 Alcohol or substance use disorder either: 1) active and determined to be incompatible with participation in the intervention through discussion with agency staff, or 2) new abstinence from alcohol or substance use disorder in past 30 days Planning to leave agency within 6 months or move out of geographic area within 12 months People who are nonEnglish speakers or who have major visual or hearing impairment will be excluded given the need to read the program materials and interact with technology.
